title: How to Make Kumbu Kacang Ijo (Mung Beans)

steps.headline: Clean the mung beans with water.
steps.description: Then, soak the mung beans in water for two hours.

steps.headline: Boil 700 ml of water.
steps.description: Add the pandan leaves. Then, put in the ginger for five minutes only, after which time, fish it out.

steps.headline: Add the mung beans to the boiling water.
steps.description: Cook until the mung beans pop and are soft.

steps.headline: Add the brown sugar when the water has slightly dried off.
Mix and stir the ingredients together until dry and well combined.
steps.description: This forms the dough base for the mung bean balls.

steps.headline: Transfer the mung bean dough to the big bowl.
steps.description: Set aside and leave until it cools down completely.

parts.name: Making the coconut pulp and milk

steps.headline: While waiting, filter (sieve) the grated coconut with 200 ml of water to make coconut milk.
Separate the coconut into two small bowls.
steps.description: For the first bowl, add the coconut pulp that you used to make the milk. In the second bowl, tip the coconut milk.

steps.headline: Add the batter.
steps.description: Dip the mung bean balls, one by one, into the batter bowl. Be sure to dip enough to cover all of the ball's surface. This will help to prevent the ball from breaking apart during frying.

steps.headline: Add the balls to the frying pan with warm vegetable oil.
steps.description: Cook them until the outer part of the balls become golden and crisp. Do this in batches. Do not try to fry too many balls at the same time.

steps.headline: Serve.
steps.description: Remove the mung bean balls from the frying pan and the kumbu kacang ijo are ready to served.

text: Preparing the mung bean dough Clean the mung beans with water. Then, soak the mung beans in water for two hours. Boil 700 ml of water. Add the pandan leaves. Then, put in the ginger for five minutes only, after which time, fish it out. Add the mung beans to the boiling water. Cook until the mung beans pop and are soft. Add the brown sugar when the water has slightly dried off.  Mix and stir the ingredients together until dry and well combined. This forms the dough base for the mung bean balls. Transfer the mung bean dough to the big bowl. Set aside and leave until it cools down completely. Making the coconut pulp and milk While waiting, filter (sieve) the grated coconut with 200 ml of water to make coconut milk.  Separate the coconut into two small bowls. For the first bowl, add the coconut pulp that you used to make the milk. In the second bowl, tip the coconut milk. Cooking the mung bean balls Add the batter. Dip the mung bean balls, one by one, into the batter bowl. Be sure to dip enough to cover all of the ball's surface. This will help to prevent the ball from breaking apart during frying. Add the balls to the frying pan with warm vegetable oil. Cook them until the outer part of the balls become golden and crisp. Do this in batches. Do not try to fry too many balls at the same time. Serve. Remove the mung bean balls from the frying pan and the kumbu kacang ijo are ready to served.
